title: Fed Doesn't Send Trading Ban Plan to Warren; U.S. Industrial Production Down; China's Growth Seen Slowing
text:
Top News

Warren Doesn't Get Fed Trading Ban Proposal as Requested

Sen. Elizabeth Warren had written to the 12 regional Fed bank presidents on Sept. 16 asking for a ban on stock trading by policy makers. She had asked for a response by Oct. 15 on plans for a ban, followed by its implementation within 60 days of her letters.

U.S. Economy

Auto-Supply Constraints Weighed on September Industrial Production

U.S. industrial production fell by a seasonally adjusted 1.3% in September from August, the sharpest decline since February, when severe winter weather in the south and central U.S. disrupted factory activity.

Yellen: Debt Limit Deal Will Keep Government Funded Through Dec. 3

In a letter to Capitol Hill leaders, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said the debt-limit deal last week "provides only a temporary reprieve" and urged lawmakers to act to ensure the government can continue to borrow money.

Amazon Seeks to Hire 150,000 Seasonal U.S. Workers

Amazon.com Inc. aims to hire 150,000 seasonal workers in the U.S., a move to get needed workers for the holidays against a tight labor market. The number matches the number that rival Walmart Inc. said it would add this year.

Zillow Says It Can't Buy Any More Homes This Year

Real-estate company Zillow Group Inc. said it will stop buying and flipping new houses in the U.S. for the remainder of this year, citing backlogs related to renovating homes and constraints for on-the-ground workers.

Key Developments Around the World

China Faces Slower Growth Path as It Pursues Longer-Term Reforms

While economists had predicted momentum to slow from the first and second quarters of the year, the Chinese economy now faces a more daunting set of challenges than had been foreseen earlier in the year, which threatens to drag growth lower.

Bank of Canada Survey Finds Widespread Hiring, Investment Plans

The central bank's quarterly business outlook survey found companies' domestic and foreign sales prospects remained strong in the late summer, with businesses that provide in-person services expecting to benefit from easing Covid-19 restrictions and pent-up consumer demand.

Indonesia Central Bank Maintains Benchmark Rate as Expected

Bank Indonesia on Tuesday kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged to continue to maintain the stability of the rupiah and support its economic recovery.

Foreign Investment Rebounds, but Strained Factories Miss Out

Foreign investment by businesses around the world surged in the first six months of 2021 as rich economies rebounded strongly from the effects of the pandemic, but fresh bets on manufacturing fell despite widespread signs that capacity isn't up to meeting resurgent demand.

Financial Regulation Roundup

GameStop Trading Frenzy Tested Resilience of Markets, SEC Says

A trading frenzy in shares of GameStop Corp. this year raised a number of questions for regulators but didn't expose major weaknesses in stock-market infrastructure, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Monday.

German Fintech N26, Valued at $9 Billion, Draws Regulator's Eye

N26 Bank GmbH said Germany's financial regulator had temporarily capped the number of new customers it can sign up, the third regulatory action in six months aimed at improving controls at the startup digital bank.

Global Investors Gain a New Way to Bet on Stocks in China

Hong Kong started trading in futures tied to an index of stocks from mainland China, giving global investors a new tool for betting on Chinese markets. The futures are linked to the MSCI China A 50 Connect Index.

Biden Administration to Constrain Use of Sanctions in Policy Shift

The Biden administration plans to limit the use of economic and financial sanctions in a shift that Treasury Department officials said should strengthen the impact of a tactic that U.S. foreign policy has relied on in recent years.

Research

SF Fed Sees Modest Inflation Impact From Pandemic Fiscal Stimulus

Pandemic-centric fiscal spending is expected to lift inflation modestly, according to a research report released Monday by the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco. The American Rescue Plan "is projected to cause a transitory increase in the vacancy-to-unemployment ratio, which translates into a core inflation rate that is about 0.3 percentage point higher per year through 2022," bank analysts wrote in the report. "The impact of the ARP on inflation rests on the transitory nature of the fiscal spending increase, but also on the stability of longer-run inflation expectations," they added. Inflation has surged well above the Federal Reserve's 2% target over recent months, which Fed officials have attributed to supply driven shocks they believe will ease as the coronavirus pandemic wanes.

Commentary

China's Economy Rests on Three Shaky Legs

What happens in 2022 appears to depend primarily on three things: how fast Beijing dials back its squeeze on the property sector, whether consumers finally perk up, and whether exporters can hang on to recent market-share gains, Nathaniel Taplin writes.

Basis Points

Small U.S. cities dominated The Wall Street Journal/Realtor.com Emerging Housing Markets Index in the third quarter, as high housing costs and remote-work opportunities drive many home buyers to seek out more living and outdoor space.

China's giant housing market slowed substantially in September, falling 3.5% from a year earlier, as debt-saddled developers cut spending and demand from home buyers waned, according to data released by China's National Bureau of Statistics. It was the first time property investment had fallen year-over-year after growing quickly since the beginning of the coronavirus pandemic.

Canadian housing starts fell in September, as construction activity pulled back in urban areas although remained high on a historical basis. Starts for the month came in at a seasonally adjusted annualized rate of 251,151 units, a 4.4% decrease from 270,744 units in August, Canada Mortgage and Housing Corp. said. (Dow Jones Newswires)

An early indicator of global trade flows developed by The Wall Street Journal points to a 2.0% rise in August from the previous month, adjusted for the seasonal ups and downs of exports of goods between countries. That marked a partial rebound from July, when the indicator fell by 2.5% in what was the first drop since March, when trade flows were hit by a blockage in the Suez Canal. (DJN)

Foreign investors purchased a net 26.3 billion Canadian dollars, or the equivalent of US$21.27 billion, in Canadian securities in August, compared with revised C$14.06 billion in Canadian securities in July, Statistics Canada said. (DJN)
